definition: Human beings considered as a group; to fill a place with people.
examples: Many people visited the museum. (noun)
Settlers peopled the new town. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: People = persons in a place; to people = to fill with persons.

definition: A living creature that is not a plant, such as a dog, bird, or fish.
examples: The zoo has many wild animals.
A fox is a clever animal.

extra.memory_tip: Animal = a living creature that can move and eat.

definition: A small wave or series of waves; to form small waves or spread outward.
examples: Wind made ripples on the pond. (noun)
Laughter rippled through the class. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Ripple = little waves that run across water (or sound across a room).

definition: A round control with numbers or marks; to make a phone call or set a control.
examples: Turn the dial to increase the volume. (noun)
Please dial the number now. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Dial = round face you twist, or the action to call.

definition: A foot lever used to control a machine or instrument; to move a bicycle by pushing the pedals.
examples: Press the brake pedal gently. (noun)
We pedalled up the hill. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Pedal = your foot’s place to push.

definition: A small part to show what the whole is like; to try or test a small amount; meant for trying.
examples: We tasted a sample of the soup. (noun)
Scientists sampled the water. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Sample = a small slice of the big thing.

definition: A thick, tropical forest with many plants and animals.
examples: Monkeys swung through the jungle.
The jungle was hot and noisy with life.

extra.memory_tip: Jungle = jam-packed forest.

definition: About what is right or wrong in behaviour; the lesson from a story.
examples: He faced a moral choice. (adjective)
The moral of the story is to be honest. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Moral = your guide about right and wrong.

definition: A large, strong building with thick walls, towers, and sometimes a moat.
examples: The castle stood high on the hill.
We crossed the bridge to the old castle.

extra.memory_tip: Castle = king’s stone house with towers.

definition: Real and true; existing in fact.
examples: The actual cost was lower than we thought.
He showed the actual photo from the trip.

extra.memory_tip: Actual = not pretend—really there.

definition: A test or court case to decide truth; to test something to see how it works.
examples: We ran a trial of the new app. (noun)
The school will trial the schedule next term. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Trial = try-all to see if it works.

definition: A round fruit with red, green, or yellow skin and crisp flesh.
examples: She packed an apple for lunch.
We baked an apple pie.

extra.memory_tip: Apple a day keeps the doctor away.

definition: A curve that winds around a centre; shaped like a spiral.
examples: A spiral of smoke rose from the chimney. (noun)
Leaves spiralled to the ground. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Spiral = spins round and round from the centre.

definition: Reasonable and based on clear thinking.
examples: That is a logical solution.
She followed a logical order in her notes.

extra.memory_tip: Logical = it ‘logs’ together and makes sense.

definition: Relating to a nation; a citizen of a particular nation.
examples: There was a national holiday. (adjective)
She is a French national. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: National = about the whole country.

definition: Relating to a particular area of a country or the world.
examples: There are regional accents in English.
We compared regional weather patterns.

extra.memory_tip: Regional = focused on one region.

definition: Related to electricity or devices that use it.
examples: An electrical fault cut the power.
Always be careful with electrical sockets.

extra.memory_tip: Electrical = runs on electric power.

definition: A railway in which the track consists of a single rail, often elevated.
examples: We rode the monorail across the city.
The airport monorail arrives every five minutes.

extra.memory_tip: Mono = one; rail = track → one-rail train.

definition: Including or involving people from many different cultures.
examples: Our school hosts a multicultural fair.
The city is proudly multicultural.

extra.memory_tip: Multicultural = many cultures together.

definition: Against the law; not allowed by rules or the government.
examples: It is illegal to drive without a licence.
Selling those items here is illegal.

extra.memory_tip: Illegal = not legal.
